ArticleInfo.ArticleTitle: Interrelatedness of Fe composition on structural and magnetic properties in Fe-doped SrRuO3 thin films

Affiliation.OrgDivision: Institute for NanoScience, Engineering and Technology (INSET), Physics Department
Institute for NanoScience, Engineering and Technology (INSET), Electrical Engineering Department
Department of Information & Electronic Materials Engineering

Abstract.Heading: Abstract
Abstract.Para: Fe-doping (up to 11 mole%) into SrRuO3 (SRO) thin films on SrTiO3 substrates decreased correlation lengths of both surface and interface. It turned out that Fe was doped in the valence state of 3+ without formation of the Fe2O3 phase, which caused orthorhombic distortion. T C values decreased from 145 K to 97 K with increasing Fe concentration (C Fe). High magnetic switching fields were observed for all Fe-doped SRO thin films and their strengths showed a linear relationship with C Fe. Detail structural characterization using synchrotron X-ray diffraction and X-ray photoemission spectroscopy were used to understand its unique magnetic switching field properties.

Section1.Heading: Introduction
Section1.Para: In this article, we report the design of Fe-doped SRO thin films in which doping was achieved during the film growth. Detailed characterizations of the microstructure are performed to explain the observed magnetic switching field properties of our thin films.

Section1.Heading: Experimental details
Section1.Para:
Fe-doped SRO thin films were grown on nominal (001) SrTiO3 substrates (MaTeck GmbH) using a pulsed laser deposition system and a KrF excimer laser (250 mJ, 10 Hz) of a wavelength λ=248 nm. Prior to deposition, the sealed deposition chamber was evacuated to a base pressure of 3×10−7 Torr. During growth, the temperature and oxygen working pressure were maintained fixed at 750 ∘C and 100 mTorr, respectively. The doping of SrRuO3 with Fe was achieved by the alternate and consecutive ablation of SRO and Fe2O3 targets. For example, in one sample, 37 and 3 laser pulses were fired at the SRO and Fe2O3 targets, respectively, and the process was repeated 450 times until the final thickness of ∼30 nm was achieved. In this letter, pulse ratios of 39:1, 38:2, and 37:3 refer to three Fe-doped SRO films synthesized so that the actual Fe concentrations, C Fe (mole%), would be 4 %, 7 %, and 11 % (i.e., SRO:Fe(4 %), SRO:Fe(7 %) SRO:Fe(11 %)), respectively. To ensure the short range ordering of Fe–O–Fe bonds, the films were repeatedly annealed during growth for 20 seconds every ∼1 Å growth. Results of this work are compared with those of a single crystal like SRO thin film grown under similar conditions [6]. Structural properties of the grown films have been investigated using synchrotron X-ray diffraction and a two-dimensional image-plate detector at the Advanced Photon Source of Argonne National Laboratory (Beamline BESSRC 12-BM-B, λ=0.563 Å). Thicknesses, interface, and surface roughness were determined from X-ray reflectivity using an in-house X-ray diffractometer (Bruker D8 Discover, λ (Cu K
α )=1.541 Å). X-ray photoemission spectroscopy (XPS, Perkin Elmer, 5400MC) with a monochromatic Al K α X-ray source (resolution: 0.1 eV) was used to determine the valence state of Fe. Magnetic properties were measured using a Superconducting Quantum Interference Device magnetometer by Quantum Design.

Section1.Heading: Results and discussion
Section1.Para:
In Fig. 1(a), synchrotron X-ray reciprocal space mapping for SRO:Fe (11 %) reveals the presence of reflections that only correspond to orthorhombic SrRuO3 with no signs of the presence of any long range ordered spinel or hexagonal Fe2O3 phases.
Here, X and Y represent position coordinates from the beam center (in pixels) in reciprocal space for each diffraction spot. The following equation is used to determine the corresponding diffraction angle θ:
$\tan 2\theta = \frac{\sqrt{( X - 1734 )^{2} + ( Y + 132 )^{2}}}{4250}$ . Figure 1(b) shows the out-of-plane and in-plane lattice parameters as a function of Fe concentration (C Fe) as determined from the synchrotron X-ray reciprocal space mappings. As shown in the figure, the out-of-plane lattice parameter increases from 3.95 Å to 3.97 Å with increasing C Fe while the in-plane lattice parameter remains nearly constant for all the films because of a strong coherent film/substrate lattice matching. Considering the tabulated radii of the different ions Fe3+ (0.73 Å) > Ru4+ (0.70 Å) > Fe4+ (0.58 Å), we explain the gradual increase of the out-of-plane lattice constant as due to local formation (and substitution) of Fe3+ bonds (rather than Fe4+) at the Ru4+ sites [7]. If Fe populated at interstitial sites, in-plane lattice parameter of Fe-doped SRO should be increased. However, Fe doping showed same in-plane lattice parameters as pure SRO in Fig. 1(b), indicating Fe ions populated at Ru sites. As shown in Fig. 1(c), Full Width at Half Maximum (FWHM) of the X-rays rocking curve of the (110) peak is nearly constant regardless of C Fe indicating that the films exhibit similar mosaic and crystalline properties. X-ray reflectivity and estimated interface and surface roughness for the SRO:Fe (7 %) film are shown in Figs. 1(d) and 1(e). Fe doping reduced interface and surface roughness but the increasing C Fe had little or no effect on the observed roughness.
Fig. 1
(a) Selected X-ray reciprocal space mapping of SRO:Fe (11 %) thin film. The out-of-plane (2 2 0)OR and in-plane (4 2 0)OR peaks (or (3 3 1)OR and
$(4\,\overline{2}\,0)_{\mathrm{OR}}$ (or
$(3\,\overline{3}\,1)_{\mathrm{OR}}$ ) profiles were collected simultaneously using an image plate detector). Units of X and Y axes are reported in pixels (pixel positions can be converted to diffraction angles according to the equation listed in [6]). (b) Changes of out-of-plane (filled circle) and in-plane lattice (open circle) constants as a function of C Fe as determined from (2 2 0)OR and (3 1 0)OR profiles in (a), respectively. (c) Relative θ-rocking FWHM of the (2 2 0)OR peak. (d) Measured and fitted reflectivity curves for SRO:Fe (7 %) thin film. (e) Interface and surface correlation lengths as a function of C Fe. Inset shows the relationship between cubic STO and orthorhombic SRO geometrical indices

The Fe-2p and O-1s photoemission spectra for SRO:Fe (11 %), displayed in Figs. 2(a) and 2(b), show a well pronounced shake-up satellite peak around 716 eV (Fig. 2(a)) characteristic of Fe3+ 3d orbitals associated with charge transfer screening at the core hole site in γ- or α-Fe2O3 [8, 9]. The presence of this peak indicates the local formation of ordered Fe3+–O–Fe3+ bonds (i.e., Fe3+–O–Fe3+ bonding chains) that extend over a very short distance without forming long range ordered structures of the γ- or α-Fe2O3 phases as demonstrated in Fig. 1. XPS measurements of the O-1s peak for SRO:Fe (11 %) reveal the presence of two well-resolved peaks at 528.8 eV and 531.1 eV separated by 2.3 eV instead of a single peak as expected for a typical pure SRO film, Fig. 2(b). The signal at ∼529 eV is routinely observed as a characteristic peak of the O2− ions in the SRO orthorhombic structure [10]. On the other hand, the 531.1 eV peak may be explained by the possible formation of oxygen vacancies, surface contamination, intrinsic structural distortions, and/or chemical shifts. Oxygen vacancies are unlikely to have formed as they were never detected in our SrRuO3 films grown under similar conditions and surface contamination can be ruled out because of the in-situ etching (Ar-sputtering) of a thin surface layer of ∼50 Å. On the other hand, Singh and Maiti have recently demonstrated that significant orthorhombic distortions in their CaRuO3 bulk materials lead to two peaks in the density of states of the oxygen core level similar to the peaks they observed with their XPS O-1s spectra [11]. The authors attribute the appearance of the two peaks in the O-1s spectra (instead of one) as due to the presence of two distinct apical and equatorial oxygen sites in the structure having different Madelung potentials. As shown above, the larger Fe3+ ions in our Fe-doped SRO films induce significant orthorhombic distortions and could very well result in a similar split of the core energy level of oxygen. Elongation of out-of-lattice constant without changing in-plane lattice constant in Fig. 1(b) supports the orthorhombic distortion. Additionally, small contributions to the 531.1 eV peak could arise from the replacement of Ru4+ ions by Fe3+ ions that are likely to result in chemical shifts in order to maintain the total charge balance in the doped material. Although Fe was expected to substitute Ru in the 4+ like SrFeO3 systems, XPS and XRD results revealed that Fe populated at Ru sites in the 3+ valence state, which is larger than Ru4+ ion, resulting in orthorhombic distortion. Since Fe2O3 is polymorphism showing versatile magnetic prosperities, magnetism of Fe-doped SRO should be intensively analyzed in order to figure out how Fe3+ interacts with Ru4+ in SRO.
Fig. 2
(a) Fe-2p and (b) O-1s photoemission spectra for the SRO:Fe (11 %) thin film

Temperature dependent magnetic susceptibility measurements are displayed in Fig. 3 as a function of C Fe. A magnetizing field was applied in the out-of-plane direction. All films exhibited ferromagnetic properties with the ferromagnetic Curie temperature T C (determined from the derivative of magnetization with respect to temperature) decreasing from 145 K to 97 K with increasing C Fe from 0 to 11 %. Furthermore, the ferromagnetic transitions in Fe-doped films are significantly broader than that of SRO. Therefore, the broad and lower magnetic transition temperatures lead us to speculate that the embedded Fe3+ ions are antiferromagnetically coupled within the Fe3+–O–Fe3+ bonding chains, thus disturbing the ferromagnetic superexchange between the Ru4+ ions.
Fig. 3
DC magnetic susceptibility of all SRO:Fe films. The inset shows T C as a function of C Fe

Figures 4(a)–(d) show the magnetization hysteresis loops of SRO and the SRO:Fe thin films. A magnetizing field up to 70 kOe was applied perpendicular (squares) and parallel (circles) to the film plane and the hysteresis curves were measured at 5 K after zero-field-cooling (ZFC). Contributions from the diamagnetic STO substrate have been subtracted [12]. All films exhibited strong magnetization in the out-of-plane direction indicating that Fe doping has little or no effect on the typical magnetic anisotropy axis of SRO [5]. A striking feature observed in Fe-doped SRO films is the generation of enhanced magnetic switching fields that begin around the same value as that of pure SRO thin films (∼1.0 kOe) followed by a pronounced kink in magnetization before the full magnetization switch is achieved at higher fields. Similar switching field were observed from SrRuO3–SrMnO3 super-lattice systems and the pining of Ru spins at SrMnO3 interface was found to be responsible for the phenomenon [13]. Similarly, the drastic enhancement in coercivity fields in Figs. 4(b)–(d) indicate the presence of freely flipping Ru spins (before kink) and strongly pinned Ru spins at the antiferromagnetic Fe3+–O–Fe3+ bonding chains. As shown in Fig. 5, stronger magnetic fields (or switching fields) are required to overcome the spin pinning energy at the Fe3+–O–Fe3+ bonding chains and cause the pinned Ru spins to flip in the direction of the applied magnetic field.
Fig. 4
Magnetization loops measured with the magnetic field applied in the out-of-plane (square) and in-plane (circle) directions for (a) pure SRO and (b) doped SRO:Fe (4 %), (c) SRO:Fe (7 %), and (d) SRO:Fe (11 %). (e) Saturated out-of-plane magnetization (M S) as a function of C Fe. (f) Linear coercivity field (H C) behavior as a function of C Fe
Fig. 5
Schematics showing origin of magnetic switching field in Fig. 4(d). Arrows in dotted square represent antiferromagntic Fe3+–O–Fe3+ bonds and the rest do Ru spins (red arrows). (2) Ru spins freely flip along magnetic field, but (3) strongly pinned Ru spins at the antiferromagnetic Fe3+–O–Fe3+ bonds induce kink. (4) As magnetic fields is getting strong enough to overcome the spin pinning energy at the Fe3+–O–Fe3+ bonding chains, the pinned Ru spins flip in the direction of the applied magnetic field

Saturated out-of-plane magnetization (M S) is shown in Fig. 4(e) as a function of C Fe. A maximum M S value is observed for SRO:Fe (4 %) before a subsequent gradual decrease upon increasing C Fe. It is worth noting here that Fe-doped SRO thin films exhibit up to ∼16 % higher saturation magnetization compared to the undoped SRO thin film. We speculate that the interactions between Ru4+–O–Fe3+ in the RuO6 chains and the magnetically dilute Fe3+ would be ferromagnetic even though the ferromagnetic coupling between Ru4+ and Fe3+ (
$\mathrm{t}_{2\mathrm{g}}^{4}\mathrm{e}_{\mathrm{g}}^{0}$ –
$\mathrm{t}_{2\mathrm{g}}^{3} \mathrm{e}_{\mathrm{g}}^{2}$ ) is theoretically predicted to be weak [14]. Thus, it can be concluded that Fe has ferromagnetic contributions in the form of Ru4+–O–Fe3+, and antiferromagnetic contributions in the form of Fe3+–O–Fe3+. The coercive fields H C are plotted as a function of C Fe in Fig. 4(f). It is interesting to note the linear increase in H C from 1.0 to 6.5 kOe upon increasing C Fe suggesting that the Fe3+–O–Fe3+ bonding chains extend uniformly over very short length-scales without forming secondary phases as described above. Otherwise, if the bonding chains were to grow to sizeable domains, H C would be expected to exhibit a nonlinear relationship with C Fe since the interacting FM-AM area with the SRO spins would be proportional to the surface area of the domain volume. Our explanation is further supported by the nearly constant FWHM and surface, interface roughness values, and the lack of evidence for the formation of large size Fe2O3 clusters shown in Fig. 1. In contrast, no significant switching fields are observed in the in-plane hysteresis curves of any of the SRO:Fe thin films indicating that the short ranged Fe3+–O–Fe3+ bonding chains populate the RuO6 chains and leave the directional chain structure mostly unaffected. Further studies are needed to determine the exact locations and bonding shapes of the Fe3+–O–Fe3+. It should be noted again that Fe3+–O–Fe3+ bonds possessed effective antiferromagnetic spins, but did not form any sizeable α-Fe2O3 phases in SrRuO3. Synchrotron X-ray measurement in Fig. 1 obviously showed that Fe was soluble even up to 11 % in SrRuO3. Also, linear relation between Fe composition and magnetic switching field proved that Fe-doped into SrRuO3 without formation of any secondary phases.

Section1.Heading: Conclusion
Section1.Para: In conclusion, it was fount that Fe was doped in the form of antiferromagnetic Fe3+–O–Fe3+ and ferromagnetic Ru4+–O–Fe3+ bonds which was within the RuO6 chains, but without the formation of long range ordered secondary phases (α-Fe2O3). Increased structural distortion due to the incorporated Fe3+–O–Fe3+ results in two split peaks of the oxygen core level and elongation of out-of-lattice constant as suggested by our XPS and X-ray measurements, respectively. Fe3+ doping significantly affects the magnetic properties of SRO by inducing larger magnetization (up to 16 %) and linearly increasing magnetic switching fields. The origin of the switching field is explained by the exchange coupling and pinning of the Ru spins to the antiferromagnetic Fe3+–O–Fe3+ bonding chains.
